basicConversations.title: Greetings and Introductions
basicConversations.context: Two people meeting for the first time
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Hola (Hello), Bien (Good), Gracias (Thank you), Me llamo (My name is), Mucho gusto (Nice to meet you)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Very good. My name is Ana.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Nice to meet you, Ana. I'm Carlos.

basicConversations.title: Ordering at a Café
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Café (Coffee), Leche (Milk), Por favor (Please), Gracias (Thank you), Cuánto (How much)

dialogue.speaker: Server
dialogue.translation: Good morning! What would you like?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.translation: No, thank you. How much is it?

basicConversations.title: At the Market
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Manzanas (Apples), Naranjas (Oranges), Plátanos (Bananas), Cuánto cuesta (How much does it cost), Quiero (I want)

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.translation: Good morning, do you have apples?

dialogue.speaker: Vendor
dialogue.translation: Yes, we have green and red apples.

basicConversations.title: Making Plans
basicConversations.context: Planning to meet with a friend
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Quieres (Do you want), Podemos (We can), Dónde (Where), Cuándo (When), Qué hora (What time)

dialogue.speaker: Friend A
dialogue.translation: Do you want to go to the movies tomorrow?

dialogue.speaker: Friend B
dialogue.translation: Perfect, we'll see each other at the cinema.

basicConversations.title: Talking About Age
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Años (Years), Tienes (You have), Iguales (Same), Verdad (True), Qué bien (How nice)

basicConversations.title: Talking About the Day
basicConversations.context: Two friends discussing the day of the week
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Día (Day), Hoy (Today), Lunes (Monday), Gusta (Like), Tampoco (Neither do I)

basicConversations.title: Colors
basicConversations.context: Two friends discussing their favorite colors
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Color (Color), Rojo (Red), Azul (Blue), Bonito (Beautiful), Encantar (To love)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you like the color red?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Yes, I like it a lot.

basicConversations.title: Talking About Food
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Hambre (Hunger), Mucha (A lot), Pizza (Pizza), Encantar (To love), Comer (To eat)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Pets
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Perro (Dog), Gato (Cat), Mascota (Pet), Lindo (Cute), Encantar (To love)

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Thank you. Do you have pets?

basicConversations.title: Talking About Where You're From
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Dónde (Where), Eres (You are), México (Mexico), Argentina (Argentina), Mucho gusto (Nice to meet you)

basicConversations.title: Asking the Time
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Hora (Time), Son las (It is), Gracias (Thank you), Nada (Nothing), Prisa (Hurry)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Family
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Hermana (Sister), Llamar (To call), Nombre (Name), Lindo (Nice), Gracias (Thank you)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Sports
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Fútbol (Soccer), Equipo (Team), Favorito (Favorite), Barcelona (Barcelona), Bien (Good)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you have a favorite team?

basicConversations.title: Feeling Sick
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Bien (Well), Enfermo (Sick), Siento (Sorry), Médico (Doctor), Tarde (Afternoon)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Are you going to the doctor?

basicConversations.title: Talking About Music
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Música (Music), Escuchar (To listen), Pop (Pop), Rock (Rock), Genial (Great)

basicConversations.title: Talking About School Supplies
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Lápiz (Pencil), Papel (Paper), Gracias (Thank you), Nada (You're welcome), Momento (Moment)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Weather
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Frío (Cold), Abrigo (Coat), Bufanda (Scarf), Idea (Idea), Cuídate (Take care)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I'm going to put on my coat.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I brought a hat and gloves.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I don't want to catch a cold.

basicConversations.title: Weekend Plans
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Sábado (Saturday), Cine (Cinema), Amigos (Friends), Divertir (To have fun), Gracias (Thank you)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What are you doing on Saturday?

basicConversations.title: Expressing Likes
basicConversations.context: Two friends discussing their favorite foods
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Chocolate (Chocolate), Pizza (Pizza), Favorita (Favorite), Rico (Delicious), También (Also)

basicConversations.title: At the Library
basicConversations.context: Two people discussing books at a library
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Libros (Books), Allá (There), Buscar (To look for), Cuentos (Stories), Elección (Choice)

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: What book are you looking for?

basicConversations.title: Talking About TV
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Tele (TV), Noche (Night), Ver (To watch), Dibujos animados (Cartoons), Divertidos (Fun)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Daily Routine
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Levantarse (To get up), Temprano (Early), Escuela (School), Caminar (To walk), Bus (Bus)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What time do you get up?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you walk or take the bus?

basicConversations.title: Asking for Help
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Ayudar (To help), Por favor (Please), Tarea (Homework), Está bien (It's okay), Nada (You're welcome)

basicConversations.title: Talking About Birthdays
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Cumpleaños (Birthday), Mayo (May), Feliz (Happy), Fiesta (Party), Amigos (Friends)

basicConversations.title: Asking for Directions
basicConversations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Calle (Street), Izquierda (Left), Derecha (Right), Cerca (Near), Lejos (Far)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Dónde está' means 'Where is' for locations
- 'Gira' means 'Turn'
- 'Sigue recto' means 'Go straight'

dialogue.speaker: Tourist
dialogue.translation: Excuse me, where is the station?

dialogue.speaker: Local
dialogue.line: No, sigue ___ y gira a la derecha.
dialogue.translation: No, go straight and turn right.

dialogue.speaker: Local
dialogue.line: No, está muy ___. Son dos minutos caminando.
dialogue.translation: No, it's very close. It's two minutes walking.

situations.title: At the Restaurant
situations.context: Ordering dinner at a Spanish restaurant
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Buenas noches (Good evening), Reserva (Reservation), Mesa (Table), Carta (Menu), Nombre (Name)

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.translation: Good evening, do you have a reservation?

situations.title: Asking for Directions
situations.context: On the street looking for a museum
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Disculpe (Excuse me), Dónde (Where), Cuadras (Blocks), Caminando (Walking), Cerca (Close)

dialogue.speaker: Tourist
dialogue.translation: Excuse me, where is the museum?

situations.title: At the Doctor's Office
situations.context: Visiting a doctor for a check-up
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Dolor (Pain), Síntomas (Symptoms), Medicamento (Medicine), Receta (Prescription), Mejor (Better)

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.translation: Since when do you have these symptoms?

situations.title: At the Hotel
situations.context: Checking in at a hotel
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Reserva (Reservation), Habitación (Room), Llave (Key), Desayuno (Breakfast), Piso (Floor)

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.translation: Good afternoon, do you have a reservation?

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.line: Su habitación está en el ___ piso.
dialogue.translation: Your room is on the third floor.

dialogue.speaker: Guest
dialogue.translation: At what time is breakfast served?

situations.title: Making Weekend Plans
situations.context: Two friends discussing weekend plans with family
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Planes (Plans), Fin de semana (Weekend), Abuelos (Grandparents), Ciudad (City), Coche (Car)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: ¿Qué ___ tienes para el fin de semana?
dialogue.translation: What plans do you have for the weekend?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I'm going to visit my grandparents.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: How nice! Do they live nearby?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Are you going by car or train?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: We're going by car with my family.

situations.title: Talking About School Subjects
situations.context: Two students discussing their favorite school subjects
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Materia (Subject), Ciencias (Science), Historia (History), Pasado (Past), Genial (Great)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What subject do you like the most?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I like science, it's very interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I like learning about the past.

situations.title: Describing a Friend
situations.context: Two friends talking about their best friend
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Amigo (Friend), Simpático (Nice), Divertido (Fun), Nombre (Name), Clase (Class)

situations.title: Talking About Daily Routine
situations.context: Two friends discussing their morning routine
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Mañana (Morning), Ducharse (To shower), Desayunar (To have breakfast), Escuela (School), Tarde (Afternoon)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: ¿Qué haces todos los días por la ___?
dialogue.translation: What do you do every morning?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I get up, shower, and have breakfast.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What time do you go to school?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: And what time do you return?

situations.title: Going Shopping
situations.context: Two friends discussing shopping for clothes
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Comprar (To buy), Chaqueta (Jacket), Color (Color), Tienda (Store), Abierta (Open)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I want to buy a new jacket.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: What color do you want it?

situations.title: Describing Weather and Clothes
situations.context: Two friends discussing weather and appropriate clothing
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Frío (Cold), Viento (Wind), Abrigo (Coat), Gorro (Hat), Guantes (Gloves)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I'm going to put on my coat.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I brought a hat and gloves.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I don't want to catch a cold.

situations.title: Ordering at a Restaurant
situations.context: A customer ordering food at a restaurant
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Pedir (To order), Hamburguesa (Hamburger), Papas (Fries), Beber (To drink), Postre (Dessert)

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.translation: Good afternoon, what would you like to order?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.line: Quiero una ___ con papas, por favor.
dialogue.translation: I want a hamburger with fries, please.

situations.title: Talking About Hobbies
situations.context: Two friends discussing their hobbies
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Tiempo libre (Free time), Guitarra (Guitar), Dibujar (To draw), Pintar (To paint), Encantar (To love)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What do you do in your free time?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I'd love to see your drawings!

situations.title: Talking About a Trip
situations.context: Two friends discussing a beach trip
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Viajar (To travel), Playa (Beach), Verano (Summer), Nadar (To swim), Helado (Ice cream)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Have you ever traveled to the beach?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Sí, el ___ pasado fui con mis padres.
dialogue.translation: Yes, last summer I went with my parents.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: A lot! We swam and ate ice cream.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Which beach did you go to?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: A una que se llama Playa ___.

situations.title: Talking About Health
situations.context: Two friends discussing health
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Sentirse (To feel), Doler (To hurt), Cabeza (Head), Médico (Doctor), Descansar (To rest)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Did you go to the doctor?

situations.title: Talking About Music
situations.context: Two friends discussing music preferences
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Música (Music), Escuchar (To listen), Pop (Pop), Rock (Rock), Genial (Great)

situations.title: Talking About School Supplies
situations.context: Two students sharing school supplies
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Lápiz (Pencil), Papel (Paper), Gracias (Thank you), Nada (You're welcome), Momento (Moment)

situations.title: Talking About Weather
situations.context: Two friends discussing the weather
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Frío (Cold), Abrigo (Coat), Bufanda (Scarf), Idea (Idea), Cuídate (Take care)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I'm going to put on my coat.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I brought a hat and gloves.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I don't want to catch a cold.

situations.title: Weekend Plans
situations.context: Two friends discussing weekend activities
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Sábado (Saturday), Cine (Cinema), Amigos (Friends), Divertir (To have fun), Gracias (Thank you)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What are you doing on Saturday?

situations.title: Expressing Likes
situations.context: Two friends discussing their favorite foods
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Chocolate (Chocolate), Pizza (Pizza), Favorita (Favorite), Rico (Delicious), También (Also)

situations.title: At the Library
situations.context: Two people discussing books at a library
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Libros (Books), Allá (There), Buscar (To look for), Cuentos (Stories), Elección (Choice)

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: What book are you looking for?

situations.title: Talking About TV
situations.context: Two friends discussing TV shows
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Tele (TV), Noche (Night), Ver (To watch), Dibujos animados (Cartoons), Divertidos (Fun)

situations.title: Talking About Daily Routine
situations.context: Two friends discussing daily schedules
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Levantarse (To get up), Temprano (Early), Escuela (School), Caminar (To walk), Bus (Bus)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What time do you get up?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you walk or take the bus?

situations.title: Asking for Help
situations.context: Two friends helping with homework
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Ayudar (To help), Por favor (Please), Tarea (Homework), Está bien (It's okay), Nada (You're welcome)

situations.title: Talking About Birthdays
situations.context: Two friends discussing birthdays
situations.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Cumpleaños (Birthday), Mayo (May), Feliz (Happy), Fiesta (Party), Amigos (Friends)

situations.title: At the Doctor
situations.context: A patient visiting the doctor with symptoms
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Síntomas (Symptoms), Garganta (Throat), Fiebre (Fever), Desde (Since), Descansar (To rest), Medicina (Medicine)
Grammar Tips: 
- Use 'me duele' for expressing pain (singular) or 'me duelen' (plural)
- 'Desde' is used to indicate when something started
- 'Necesitas' is the informal 'you need' form
- 'Lo haré' uses the future tense to express future actions

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.line: Me duele la ___ y tengo fiebre.
dialogue.translation: My throat hurts and I have a fever.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.translation: You need to rest and take medicine.

situations.title: Asking for Directions
situations.context: A tourist asking for directions to a bank
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Banco (Bank), Supermercado (Supermarket), Lejos (Far), Caminando (Walking), Al lado de (Next to)
Grammar Tips: 
- '¿Dónde está...?' is used to ask for location of singular objects
- 'Al lado de' is a prepositional phrase meaning 'next to'
- 'Caminando' is the gerund form of 'caminar'
- 'De nada' is a common response to 'gracias'

dialogue.speaker: Tourist
dialogue.translation: Excuse me, where is the bank?

situations.title: Talking About Pets
situations.context: Two friends discussing their pets
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Mascotas (Pets), Perro (Dog), Se llama (Is named), Raza (Breed), Labrador (Labrador)
Grammar Tips: 
- 'Se llama' is the reflexive form of 'llamar'
- 'Tienes' is the informal 'you have' form
- 'Es un' is used for masculine singular nouns
- 'Qué' is used for asking 'what' in questions

situations.title: Making a Phone Call
situations.context: A person calling a friend's house
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Está (Is), En casa (At home), Regresa (Returns), Llamo (I call), Después (Later)
Grammar Tips: 
- 'Está' is the third person singular form of 'estar'
- 'Regresa' is the third person singular form of 'regresar'
- 'Llamo' is the first person singular form of 'llamar'
- 'Hasta luego' is a common farewell phrase

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.translation: Do you know what time she returns?

situations.title: Talking About Food
situations.context: Two friends discussing lunch
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Almorzar (To have lunch), Arroz (Rice), Pollo (Chicken), Cocinar (To cook), Preparar (To prepare)
Grammar Tips: 
- 'Almorzaste' is the past tense form of 'almorzar'
- 'Comí' is the first person singular past tense of 'comer'
- 'Estaba' is the imperfect tense of 'estar'
- 'Lo preparó' uses the third person singular past tense

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What did you have for lunch today?

situations.title: Planning a Trip
situations.context: Two friends talking about vacation plans
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Vacaciones (Vacation), Montaña (Mountain), Caminar (To walk/hike), Fotos (Photos), Emocionado (Excited)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Vas' is the second person singular of 'ir' (to go)
- 'Vamos a' + infinitive is a way to express future plans (We are going to...)
- 'Estoy emocionado' uses the present tense of 'estar' to express a feeling

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Where are you going on vacation?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: To the mountains with my family.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: What are you all going to do there?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: We're going to walk and take photos.

situations.title: Going to the Movies
situations.context: Two friends deciding to watch a movie
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Película (Movie), Cine (Cinema), Entradas (Tickets), Empezar (To start), Preferir (To prefer)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Quieres' is the second person singular of 'querer' (to want)
- 'Empieza' is the third person singular present form of 'empezar'
- 'Prefieres' is the second person singular present form of 'preferir'

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you want to go to the movies tonight?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Yes! What movie are we going to watch?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Hay una comedia nueva en el ___.
dialogue.translation: There’s a new comedy at the cinema.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: What time does the movie start?

situations.title: Talking About Work
situations.context: Two friends discussing jobs
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Trabajar (To work), Empresa (Company), Gusta (To like), Estrés (Stress), Programador (Programmer)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Trabajas' is the second person singular present form of 'trabajar'
- 'Te gusta' means 'do you like it?'
- 'Es' is used for permanent states or identities (like professions)

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Sí, pero a veces hay mucho ___.
dialogue.translation: Yes, but sometimes there's a lot of stress.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: I’m a programmer. I design mobile apps.

situations.title: Meeting Someone New
situations.context: Two people meeting for the first time
situations.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Nombre (Name), Encantado/a (Nice to meet you), Conocer (To meet), Edad (Age), Lugar (Place)
Grammar Tips:
- '¿Cómo te llamas?' means 'What is your name?'
- 'Tengo' is used to express age (literally: I have __ years)
- 'Soy de' means 'I am from'

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Me llamo Ana. ¿Y tú? ¿Cuál es tu ___?
dialogue.translation: My name is Ana. And you? What’s your name?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I’m Marcos. Nice to meet you.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Same here. Where are you from?

practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Camisa (Shirt), Talla (Size), Mediana (Medium), Color (Color), Precio (Price)

dialogue.speaker: You
dialogue.translation: Yes, thanks. I'm looking for a shirt.

practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: Cine (Cinema), Noche (Night), Hora (Time), Película (Movie), Vemos (We'll see each other)

dialogue.speaker: Friend
dialogue.translation: Do you want to go to the movies tonight?

dialogue.speaker: You
dialogue.translation: Yes, I'd like to. What time?

dialogue.speaker: You
dialogue.translation: Perfect, we'll see each other there.

practiceDialogues.title: Making a Reservation
practiceDialogues.context: A customer making a restaurant reservation
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Reserva (Reservation), Personas (People), Día (Day), Hora (Time), Nombre (Name)
Grammar Tips: 
- 'Quisiera' is the conditional form of 'querer' used for polite requests
- 'Para' is used to indicate purpose or destination
- 'A las ocho' uses the preposition 'a' for specific times
- 'A nombre de' is a fixed phrase meaning 'under the name of'

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: Good afternoon, how can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Quisiera hacer una ___ para dos personas.
dialogue.translation: I would like to make a reservation for two people.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: For what day and at what time?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Para el sábado a las ___ de la noche.
dialogue.translation: For Saturday at eight in the evening.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Under the name of Carla Gómez.

practiceDialogues.title: Talking About a Book
practiceDialogues.context: Two people discussing a book one of them read
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Libro (Book), Viajes (Travel), Prestar (To lend), Descripciones (Descriptions)
Grammar Tips:
- '¿Has leído?' uses the present perfect tense (Have you read?)
- 'Te lo traigo' = I’ll bring it to you

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: Have you read any interesting book lately?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Sí, terminé uno sobre ___ por Europa.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I finished one about travels through Europe.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: A lot. The descriptions were very detailed.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: Can you lend it to me?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Sure, I’ll bring it to you tomorrow.

practiceDialogues.title: Asking About Work
practiceDialogues.context: Two friends talking about a job
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Empresa (Company), Programador (Programmer), Estrés (Stress), Aplicaciones (Apps)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Dónde trabajas' = Where do you work?
- 'Diseño' is first person present tense of 'diseñar' (to design)

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Sí, pero a veces es un poco ___.
dialogue.translation: Yes, but sometimes it’s a bit stressful.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: And what do you do exactly?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: I’m a programmer and I design mobile apps.

practiceDialogues.title: Going to the Doctor
practiceDialogues.context: A patient visiting the doctor due to fatigue
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Cansado (Tired), Dormir (To sleep), Análisis (Tests), Ayunar (To fast)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Me siento' means 'I feel'
- 'Duerme' is third-person form of 'dormir'

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: Doctor, I feel very tired lately.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Do you sleep well at night?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.line: Duermo poco, y me ___ varias veces.
dialogue.translation: I sleep little and wake up several times.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Vamos a hacer unos ___ para revisar.
dialogue.translation: We’ll do some tests to check.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Sí, por lo menos ocho horas antes del ___.
dialogue.translation: Yes, at least 8 hours before the exam.

practiceDialogues.title: Talking About a Hobby
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Pintar (To paint), Manualidades (Crafts), Pasatiempo (Hobby), Obras (Works)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Desde hace' means 'for (a period of time)'
- 'Te las enseño' = I’ll show them to you

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: What do you do when you're not working?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: I like to paint and do crafts.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: How long have you been painting?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: For five years, as a hobby.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.translation: Do you have photos of your works?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Yes, I’ll show them to you later.

practiceDialogues.title: Discussing a Movie
practiceDialogues.context: Two people talking about a film they saw
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Cine (Cinema), Película (Movie), Acción (Action), Comedia (Comedy)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Fuiste' is the past tense of 'ir' (you went)
- 'Valió la pena' = Was it worth it?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.line: ¿___ al cine el fin de semana?
dialogue.translation: Did you go to the movies this weekend?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.line: Sí, vi la nueva ___ de acción.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I saw the new action movie.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: It was entertaining, but a bit predictable.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.line: A mí me gustan más las ___.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Then that one’s not for you.

practiceDialogues.title: Talking About Travel Plans
practiceDialogues.context: Friends discussing a summer trip to Spain
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Viajar (To travel), Ciudades (Cities), Reservar (To book), Vuelos (Flights)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Estoy pensando en' = I'm thinking about
- 'Vas solo' = Are you going alone?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.line: Estoy pensando en ___ a España este verano.
dialogue.translation: I’m thinking about traveling to Spain this summer.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: How exciting! Which cities will you go to?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: Are you going alone or with someone?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.line: Voy con mi ___. Ya reservamos los vuelos.
dialogue.translation: I’m going with my sister. We already booked the flights.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.translation: You're going to have a great time!

practiceDialogues.title: At the Supermarket
practiceDialogues.context: A customer asks for help in the supermarket
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Frutas (Fruits), Vegetales (Vegetables), Estantería (Shelf), Kilo (Kilogram), Precio (Price)
Grammar Tips:
- '¿Dónde están...?' is used to ask for the location of something.
- 'Cuánto cuestan' is used to ask for the price in plural.
- 'Quiero' is the first person singular of 'querer' (to want).

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: At the back, next to the vegetables.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Thank you. Do you have green apples?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Yes, they are on the second shelf.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: How much do they cost per kilo?

practiceDialogues.title: Ordering Coffee
practiceDialogues.context: A customer orders coffee at a café
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Café (Coffee), Leche (Milk), Azúcar (Sugar), Grande (Large), Pequeño (Small), Tostada (Toast)
Grammar Tips:
- '¿Qué desea tomar?' is a polite way to ask what someone wants to drink.
- 'Para llevar o para aquí' is used to ask if the order is for takeout or to consume at the café.
- 'Quisiera' is a more polite way of saying 'I would like'.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Good morning, what would you like to drink?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Very well. To go or for here?

practiceDialogues.title: Renting an Apartment
practiceDialogues.context: A person is looking for an apartment to rent
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Apartamento (Apartment), Alquiler (Rent), Habitaciones (Rooms), Iluminación (Lighting), Planta (Floor)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Estoy buscando' is the present progressive form, meaning 'I am looking for'.
- 'Tenemos' is the present form of 'tener' (to have).
- 'Me gustaría' is a polite way to say 'I would like'.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Hola, estoy ___ un apartamento en esta zona.
dialogue.translation: Hello, I am looking for an apartment in this area.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Of course, what type of apartment do you need?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Uno de dos ___ y con buena iluminación.
dialogue.translation: One with two rooms and good lighting.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Tenemos uno disponible en la tercera ___.
dialogue.translation: We have one available on the third floor.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: How much is the monthly rent?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I would like to see it before deciding.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Of course, I can show it right now.

practiceDialogues.title: At the Pharmacy
practiceDialogues.context: A person is buying medicine at the pharmacy
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Dolor (Pain), Cabeza (Head), Pastillas (Pills), Jarabe (Syrup), Tomar (To take)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Necesito' is the first-person singular form of 'necesitar' (to need).
- '¿Cuál es mejor?' is used to compare two or more options.
- 'Debe tomar' is a formal way to give instructions.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Buenas tardes, necesito algo para el ___ de cabeza.
dialogue.translation: Good afternoon, I need something for my headache.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Do you want pills or syrup?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: I prefer pills. Which ones do you recommend?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Which one is better for strong pain?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: El ibuprofeno es más ___ en esos casos.
dialogue.translation: Ibuprofen is more effective in those cases.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Aquí tiene, debe tomar una cada ___ horas.
dialogue.translation: Here you go, you must take one every eight hours.

practiceDialogues.title: Booking a Flight
practiceDialogues.context: A traveler books a flight at a travel agency
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview:
Key words to remember: Vuelo (Flight), Pasajero (Passenger), Equipaje (Luggage), Directo (Direct), Ventanilla (Window seat)
Grammar Tips:
- 'Quisiera' is a polite way of saying 'I would like'.
- 'Tenemos un vuelo' means 'We have a flight available'.
- '¿Puedo elegir?' is a way to ask for options.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Quisiera reservar un ___ a Buenos Aires.
dialogue.translation: I would like to book a flight to Buenos Aires.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: For what date and how many passengers?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Para el 15 de mayo, solo un ___.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Tenemos un vuelo directo a las 10 de la ___ y otro con escala a las 5 de la tarde.
dialogue.translation: We have a direct flight at 10 in the morning and another with a stopover at 5 in the afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Do you want an aisle seat or a window seat?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Listo, su reserva está hecha. No olvide su ___ de identidad para el vuelo.
dialogue.translation: Done, your reservation is confirmed. Don't forget your ID for the flight.

practiceDialogues.title: At the Pharmacy
practiceDialogues.context: A customer talks to a pharmacist about medicine
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: medicina (medicine), receta (prescription), fiebre (fever), jarabe (syrup), farmacia (pharmacy)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Buenos días, necesito comprar una ___ para la fiebre.
dialogue.translation: Good morning, I need to buy medicine for the fever.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: Do you have a doctor's prescription?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Muy bien. ¿Tiene alguna ___ a los medicamentos?
dialogue.translation: Very well. Are you allergic to any medications?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: No, I don’t have any allergies.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Le recomiendo este ___ para la fiebre.
dialogue.translation: I recommend this syrup for the fever.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: How often should I take it?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Cada seis horas. Gracias por visitar nuestra ___.
dialogue.translation: Every six hours. Thanks for visiting our pharmacy.

practiceDialogues.title: Job Interview
practiceDialogues.context: A candidate is being interviewed for a job
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: entrevista (interview), experiencia (experience), puesto (position), habilidades (skills), disponibilidad (availability)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Buenos días, gracias por venir a la ___.
dialogue.translation: Good morning, thank you for coming to the interview.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Do you have prior experience in this field?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Sí, trabajé dos años en un puesto muy ___.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I worked for two years in a similar position.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Tengo habilidades en comunicación y en gestión de ___.
dialogue.translation: I have skills in communication and project management.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: ¿Cuál es su ___ para comenzar si lo contratamos?
dialogue.translation: What is your availability to start if we hire you?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Estoy disponible para comenzar la próxima ___.
dialogue.translation: I’m available to start next week.

practiceDialogues.title: Renting an Apartment
practiceDialogues.context: A person visits a real estate agency to find an apartment
practiceDialogues.vocabularyPreview: Key words to remember: alquiler (rent), contrato (contract), muebles (furniture), depósito (deposit), servicios (utilities)

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Busco un apartamento en ___ para alquilar.
dialogue.translation: I'm looking for an apartment downtown to rent.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.translation: What budget are you looking for?

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.line: Un máximo de 800 euros con los ___ incluidos.
dialogue.translation: A maximum of 800 euros with utilities included.

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Tenemos uno disponible, completamente ___ y céntrico.
dialogue.translation: We have one available, fully furnished and central.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Is it a monthly or yearly contract?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: El contrato es por un año con un ___ de un mes.
dialogue.translation: The contract is for a year with a one-month deposit.

dialogue.speaker: Person A
dialogue.translation: Can I see the apartment before deciding?

dialogue.speaker: Person B
dialogue.line: Claro, podemos ir a verlo esta misma ___.
dialogue.translation: Of course, we can go see it this afternoon.
